Award.AwardTitle: Center for Design of Analog-Digital Integrated Circuits - NSF I/UCRC Phase III
Award.AbstractNarration:
Full Center Proposal (Phase III) for an I/UCRC for the Center for Design of Analog-Digital Integrated Circuits (CDADIC)

0968877 Washington State University; John Ringo

CDADIC is proposing a Phase III support (third five-year period) for the Center, including support for central personnel, evaluation and research. The lead of the proposed Center will be Washington State University (WSU) with site locations at the University of Washington (UW) and Oregon State University (OSU).

CDADIC was established in 1989, and is currently a self-sustaining Center that continues to operate under the IUCRC model. The Center's research focus is on the design and development of analog and mixed-signal circuits and systems. While CDADIC has made numerous advances in this area over the past two decades, the demand for more advanced circuit design technology continues to grow as does the need to address the critical national concern of a shrinking domestic workforce in this field. In the coming years, the Center will continue to provide new technology and highly trained employees for this industry.

CDADIC has made significant contributions and will continue to do so to the semiconductor industry and society. The Center has contributed to economic growth through new technology development and transfer, and new technologies have been transferred to industry over the years. Industry partners provide a mechanism for the incorporation of Center output into commercial products. The wider utilization of devices developed for DoD in commercial applications is a routine component of the Center business practices. Since its inception, CDADIC has provided research and educational opportunities to approximately 500 students, with nearly 90% of its graduates going into industry. CDADIC's educational objectives are well aligned with NSF goals, specifically the Center commitment to the integration of research and education in order to produce highly trained analog/mixed-signal designers for employment in industry. Under-represented students are recruited through a variety of mechanisms such as REU awards, and recent related research funding resulted in a domestic student workforce development initiative.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Center for the Design of Analog-Digital Integrated Circuits (CDADIC) conducts research that benefits many industries in the country as well as educates and trains graduate and undergraduate students who will eventually contribute to many disciplines as valuable employees. This workforce development is considered a major outcome of the IUCRC Phase III award to CDADIC.  The center’s research performed by world-class faculty and their students contributes to advancements in fields such as healthcare, solar energy, biomedical, aerospace, national security, automobile, communications, sustainable energy, and others. Because of an ever-increasing interest in analog circuit design to support technology development for industrial applications, the center is well positioned to respond to the R&D needs of these associated industries.

All CDADIC students are actively engaged in their respective CDADIC research projects and advised by the project PI, as well as by industry partners. Students learn fundamental research skills and theory, have experience in laboratory facilities using state-of-the-art tools and software, gain experience across the entire spectrum of chip fabrication and testing, and are trained by faculty and industry engineers in a hands-on environment. Students are also required to write reports, contribute to professional papers under the guidance of their faculty advisor, present their research results to their peers and at CDADIC semiannual meetings, as well as other conferences and on location at industry member sites. All students are required to prepare posters and present them at center meetings. All students also have internship opportunities with industry partners to help advance their training and development in the field.

Another important outcome of the Phase III award is technology transfer to the CDADIC member companies that includes IP rights from center universities. An important form of technology transfer is the opportunity for the member companies to hire talented well-trained students as employees. In fact many member companies believe that is the highest payoff for their memberships. Results of the research are transferred through presentations given at company sites and broadly disseminated through associated publications and through presentations at numerous national and international conferences. Center faculty also give short courses and workshops in their area of research specialization. Publications such as NSF’s bi-annual Compendium of Technology Breakthroughs and the CDADIC website further help disseminate center research.

During the award period approximately 50 individual research projects were funded and over 65 students participated in and contributed to the successful outcome of these research projects. Many of these students are now employees contributing to important microelectronics technology development in major national corporations.

 


Last Modified: 08/11/2016
Modified by: John A Ringo
